greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows, X^n * [1,0,0,0,...]; where X = an infinite tridiagonal matrix with (1,0,1,0,1,...) in the main and subsubdiagonals and (1,1,1,...) in the subdiagonal.
comment: Can also be seen as a triangle where each entry is the sum of two terms above it in previous row (as in Pascal's triangle) plus one term above it two rows back, see also A059317. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jun 30 2012
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Rows n = 1..100 of triangle, flattened
S. Samieinia, The number of continuous curves in digital geometry, Port. Math. 67 (1) (2010) 75-89
Index entries for triangles and arrays related to Pascal's triangle
example: First few rows of the triangle are:
program: f ws vs = vs' : f vs vs' where
vs' = zipWith3 (\r s x -> r + s + x)
results.author: _Gary W. Adamson_ & _Roger L. Bagula_, May 26 2008
